rules: Rule1: If a medical procedure requires pre-approval, then the insurance claim is reimbursed.
Rule2: Whenever an insurance claim is approved, it is reimbursed.
Rule3: If medical documentation is complete, then the insurance claim is processed.
Rule4: Medical documentation is complete or incomplete.
Rule5: In the event that medical documentation is incomplete, the insurance claim is approved.
Rule6: An insurance claim being investigated implies that it is denied.
Rule7: An insurance claim that is denied is not fraudulent.
Rule8: The submission of an insurance claim leads to its approval.
Rule9: Given that an insurance policy is valid, if the insurance claim is processed, it is submitted.
Rule10: Either an appeal is filed for the insurance claim, or complete medical documentation results in the claim being approved.
Rule11: A prescription drug requiring pre-approval entails that the insurance claim is reimbursed.
Rule12: When an audit is triggered for an insurance claim, the claim is reviewed.
Rule13: An insurance claim being escalated means that an appeal is not filed for it.
Rule14: A routine medical procedure necessitates pre-approval.
Rule15: A medical procedure is either routine or experimental.
Rule16: If a medical procedure is covered by an insurance plan, then an experimental procedure implies that a prescription drug requires pre-approval.
Rule17: Should a medical procedure not be covered by an insurance plan, then if it is experimental, a prescription drug requires pre-approval.
Rule18: A medical procedure is in-network or out-of-network.
Rule19: An out-of-network medical procedure is not covered by an insurance plan.
Rule20: Either a medical procedure is an emergency, or an in-network procedure being covered by an insurance plan holds.
Rule21: If it is not the case that complete medical documentation leads to approval of the insurance claim, then the claim is fraudulent.
Rule22: Assuming that complete medical documentation does not result in approval of the insurance claim, the claim is investigated.
Rule23: If it is not true that a reviewed insurance claim is escalated, then the claim has a minor discrepancy.
Rule24: If it is not the case that the negation of "a reviewed insurance claim is escalated" implies no minor discrepancy, then the claim involves major fraud.
facts: Fact1: An insurance policy is valid.
Fact2: An audit is triggered for an insurance claim.
Fact3: An insurance claim does not involve major fraud.
Fact4: A medical procedure is not an emergency.
